title: Foreign Office warns British tourists of ‘high threat’ from terrorism in Egypt
text:
Foreign Office warns British tourists of ‘high threat’ from terrorism in Egypt Adv: 
Jul 17, 2015 ISIS terrorists in Egypt attacked patrol ship off the coast of Sinai causing it to burst into flames Adv: 
British tourists are being warned that there is a ‘high threat’ from terrorism in Egypt after ISIS attacked a naval patrol ship off the coast of Sinai. 
The attack yesterday was in a region popular with tourists, including the beach resort of Sharm el Sheikh. 
But increased security around the holiday destination - which 900,000 Britons travel to each year - has so far meant it is considered safe to travel to. 
However as ISIS jihadists have become better equipped and gain influence in the Egyptian peninsula, advice from the Foreign Office could change in the future. 
Sinai Province, formerly known as Ansar Bayt al-Maqdis, pledged its allegiance to IS in Syria and Iraq last November. 
Two months previously, IS extremists urged militants in Egypt’s Sinai Peninsula to continue with beheadings and attacks against security forces. 
In the last few months IS in the northern part of the peninsula have carried out multiple attacks. 
Sharm el Sheikh is in the southern part of the peninsula. 
Earlier this month militants killed dozens of soldiers as it attacked multiple military checkpoints and attempted for the first time to control a small pocket of territory in the Sinai desert. 
Egypt’s army said more than 100 militants and 17 soldiers were killed in the deadliest fighting in years. 
The jihadi group attacked the town of Sheikh Zuwaid, a few miles from Egypt’s border with Gaza and Israel. 
Updated advice from the FCO at the weekend said: ‘There is a high threat from terrorism.’ 
The Government had advised against all travel to North Sinai due to terrorist attacks. 
But ‘enhanced security measures’ in place to protect the Sharm el Sheikh and Hurghada resort areas mean it is considered safe to travel there. 
Their advice says the FCO is constantly reviewing the threat to British nationals from international terrorism.
